title: Thinking About Thinking: The Art of Prompt Framing
text:
---
title: "Thinking About Thinking: Early Lessons from A Brief History of Intelligence"
author: "Alex Rosen"
date: "October 15, 2025"
categories:
    - ai
    - studying
    - reading
---



How the Shape of a Question Shapes the Mind


The Image




Prompt Engineering Graphic



The Copy Paste

When we talk about AI “prompting,” we usually mean typing an instruction and waiting for a response.
But if we zoom out, prompting is something much older — it’s the art of asking the right kind of question to elicit intelligence, whether from humans or machines.
The way we frame a prompt determines not only the answer we get, but the kind of thinking that happens inside the system.
A good prompt doesn’t just extract information — it creates a cognitive context.


Framing vs. Instructing
When we instruct, we tell an AI (or a person) what to do.
When we frame, we shape the space in which ideas emerge.
For example: - “Write a poem about the ocean.” → A task.
- “If the ocean could speak, what would it tell the moon?” → A frame.
The second prompt engages metaphor, perspective, and imagination.
It’s not longer a command — it’s a mental environment.
AI systems, especially large language models, respond dramatically to framing.
They adapt tone, scope, and depth based on subtle contextual cues — mirroring how human creativity responds to open-ended or constraining situations.


The Prompt and Response

Prompt


Explain how “prompt framing” can lead to more original or creative outputs from an AI system.


Response


Prompt framing encourages AI to explore conceptual associations rather than literal completions.
By shifting tone or perspective, we engage different latent regions in the model’s memory — the linguistic equivalent of creative mood lighting.
This mirrors how human brainstorming works: the broader the mental space, the more novel the idea.




Reflection

Reading about prompt engineering often feels like reading a user manual.
But prompt framing feels more like reading philosophy — it’s about how a mind is guided by questions.
I’ve noticed that when I write prompts like “explain,” I get information.
When I write prompts like “imagine,” I get insight.
It makes me think that prompting is really a mirror — showing us how we guide our own thinking.
In a sense, good prompting isn’t about controlling AI.
It’s about collaborating with it — setting up conditions where both the human and the model can think more creatively.




Prompt Engineering Graphic

title: Vibe Coding: Finding Flow in Software Development
text:
When most people think about programming, they picture solving technical problems or shipping features. But there’s another side to coding — one that feels less like work and more like entering a state of flow. This is what I like to call vibe coding.



Vibe coding isn’t about deadlines, bug tickets, or sprint goals. It’s about writing code for the sake of focus, creativity, and momentum.
In practice, this might mean: - Putting on music that helps you focus
- Cleaning up your environment and editor so distractions disappear
- Building something small, experimental, or even silly — just to see where it goes
It’s the programming equivalent of sketching in a notebook: low-pressure, creative, and surprisingly rewarding.




Modern development is often fast-paced and outcome-driven. While productivity is important, it can also lead to burnout if every coding session is framed around efficiency. Vibe coding offers a counterbalance — a reminder that programming can be playful and exploratory.
Benefits include: - Improved creativity: experimenting without constraints often leads to unexpected ideas.
- Sustained motivation: coding becomes something you look forward to, not just a task list.
- Skill growth: practice in a low-stakes environment helps sharpen intuition and technique.




If you want to bring vibe coding into your own workflow, here are some ways to start: 1. Curate a playlist: lo-fi beats, ambient soundtracks, or anything that keeps you engaged without distraction.
2. Set the stage: dim lights, a clear desk, maybe even a favorite drink nearby.
3. Pick a fun project: it could be a visualization of your Spotify history, a quirky bot, or a small tool only you will ever use.
4. Let go of outcomes: the point isn’t to finish — it’s to explore.




Coding doesn’t always have to be serious. Sometimes the best way to unlock creativity, reduce stress, and rediscover joy in programming is to let yourself vibe with the process.
So next time you sit down to write code, try setting aside the pressure of productivity. Put on some music, open a blank file, and let the vibes lead you — you might be surprised by what you create.

title: Thinking About Thinking: Early Lessons from A Brief History of Intelligence
text:
From Reinforcement to Simulation


The Image




A Brief History of Intelligence Graphic



The Copy Paste

In A Brief History of Intelligence, Max Bennett continues his evolutionary map of the mind — moving from simple reactive intelligence to systems capable of prediction and simulation.
If the earlier stages (Reflex Agent and Reinforcement Learner) taught organisms how to respond and learn, this next one teaches them how to imagine.


Breakthrough #3 – The Simulating Brain
Bennett calls this the emergence of the simulator — a mind that can model the world before acting.
This stage appears in mammals, who evolved the ability to mentally test scenarios before committing to them.

The brain develops a sort of “inner movie,” replaying or forecasting outcomes.
Structures like the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex support this imaginative rehearsal.
Evolutionarily, this reduced risk — organisms could think before they leap.

In Bennett’s framing, this moment marks the dawn of planning, creativity, and fictional thought.
It’s no longer about reacting or learning from past outcomes — it’s about running experiments in the mind.


The Prompt and Response

Prompt


Summarize Bennett’s idea of the “Simulating Brain.”
How does it compare to how modern AI models simulate possible outcomes?


Response


Bennett’s “Simulating Brain” is a mental engine for prediction.
It allows organisms to rehearse, plan, and imagine — turning experience into possibility.
In AI terms, this aligns with generative modeling: systems like GPT simulate linguistic and conceptual futures.
Both biological and artificial simulators operate by sampling from past patterns to envision what could come next.




Reflection

This chapter made me think about how simulation changes everything.
A reinforcement learner remembers what worked.
A simulator invents what might work.
That shift — from repetition to imagination — feels like the essence of creativity.
It’s also where AI becomes eerily familiar: when a model “imagines” text, storylines, or code completions, it’s doing a faint echo of what mammals evolved millions of years ago.
What’s striking in Bennett’s account is that imagination isn’t fluff — it’s survival.
To simulate is to survive longer, to waste fewer moves, to explore the future safely.
Reading this, I started seeing GPT not as a black box, but as part of this long continuum of simulation — an artificial cousin to the same cognitive mechanism that lets us daydream, rehearse conversations, or picture tomorrow.




A Brief History of Intelligence Graphic

title: Using LLMs to Write Emails
text:
Displaying LLM Outputs


The Copy Paste




Writing Emails at University


Here’s a short example of ChatGPT writing an email


The Email Draft
This week I had to email a professor about missing class for a family commitment. Normally, I would just write it myself, but I wanted to see how ChatGPT would handle the situation. I asked:
“Write me a polite email to my professor explaining I will miss class on Friday due to a family event.”
The model produced the following draft:

Subject: Request to Miss Class on Friday
Dear Professor,
I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to let you know that I will not be able to attend class on Friday due to a family event. I will make sure to catch up on the material covered. Thank you for your understanding.
Sincerely, [Your Name]

I thought this was actually pretty close to what I’d send. The tone was respectful and professional, but it was also a little too generic. I edited it to include the course name and asked if there was anything I should review before the next class.
This showed me that while ChatGPT is a good starting point, I still need to personalize the response to sound like me.


Some alternatives


The Quote


Write me a polite email to my professor about missing class Of course! Would you like me to keep it formal, or more casual?


Changing Background Colors


Of course! Would you like me to keep it formal, or more casual?


Combination of both!

Prompt

<blockquote>
    Write me a polite email to my professor about missing class
</blockquote>

Response

<blockquote>
    Of course! Would you like me to keep it formal, or more casual?
</blockquote>



Integrating responses

This week I wanted to explore how GPT-5 handles student communication tasks. We often hear about people using it for essays or coding, but I think everyday uses like emailing professors are just as important.
When I tested it, the response was professional and grammatically correct, but also generic. In practice, I’d use it as a template, then tweak details to make sure it sounds like me.
This made me think about how LLMs shape communication: they’re great at giving us a baseline of clarity and politeness, but personalization still matters — especially in academic settings where tone can affect relationships.

title: Thinking About Thinking: Early Lessons from A Brief History of Intelligence
text:
The Evolution of Intelligence


The Image




A Brief History of Intelligence Graphic



The Copy Paste

Here’s what stood out to me from the first few chapters of Max Bennett’s A Brief History of Intelligence — especially his breakdown of how intelligence evolved in stages.


The Early Stages
Bennett starts with a bold idea: that intelligence isn’t just something humans have — it’s something that emerged layer by layer over millions of years.
He introduces the five big breakthroughs in cognitive evolution. The first two especially caught my attention:

The Reflex Agent — basic stimulus–response behavior, like an organism pulling away from danger.

The Reinforcement Learner — creatures start remembering what worked, adjusting their behavior based on outcomes.

These sound simple, but Bennett argues that even these small steps set the stage for everything that followed — emotion, planning, and abstract thought.


The Prompt and Response

Prompt

<blockquote>
    Summarize the first part of *A Brief History of Intelligence* and explain how it connects to AI.
</blockquote>

Response

<blockquote>
    The early chapters trace how natural intelligence evolved in discrete steps — each solving a problem of survival.  
    Reflexes led to learning, learning led to modeling the world, and eventually to planning and reasoning.  
    Bennett’s argument suggests that modern AI mirrors this pattern: large language models are just another “layer” — machines learning by reinforcement and prediction.
</blockquote>



Reflection

What I like about Bennett’s approach is how biological and computational his story feels at the same time. It makes AI feel less like magic and more like an extension of natural evolution — a continuation of the same logic that built the human brain.
Reading this, I started to think of AI as part of a long timeline, not as something new, but as a new way of organizing old ideas about intelligence.




A Brief History of Intelligence Graphic

title: Image Generation with ChatGPT
text:
Generating Images with ChatGPT
For this experiment, I tested how an LLM with image-generation can create different visuals from slightly different prompts.
Prompt A: “Generate an image of a cat sitting on a couch.”
Prompt B: “Generate an image of a cat lounging on a couch with sunglasses.”
The first result was a standard realistic-looking cat image.
The second result added humor and personality, showing a playful cat with sunglasses.
This shows that small wording changes don’t just shift text output, but also the visual style of generated images. It highlights how careful prompt wording can make the difference between a generic picture and something more creative or entertaining.



Prompt A: Cat sitting on a couch





Prompt B: Cat lounging with sunglasses

title: Cleaning Up Messy Notes with GPT
text:
Displaying LLM Outputs


The Image




Sample output



The Copy Paste

Here’s an example of ChatGPT rewriting messy lecture notes


The Organized Notes
In class this week my notes came out really messy. Lots of half-sentences and random words. I wanted to see if GPT-5 could make them clearer, so I asked:
“Rewrite these notes into a clean bullet point list.”
It worked well — the output grouped ideas into Definitions, Formulas, and Examples. It was much easier to study from than my original scribbles.


Combination of both!

Prompt

<blockquote>
    Rewrite my messy class notes into a clear bullet point list
</blockquote>

Response

<blockquote>
    Sure! I’ve cleaned them up and organized them into sections.
</blockquote>



Reflection

This showed me how useful GPT can be for studying. It doesn’t just fix grammar — it makes notes more structured and organized. I’d still double-check details, but as a study helper it really saves time.

title: Sports Prompts and Response Sensitivity
text:
Prompting
For my first test, I wanted to see how small changes in prompts affect how an LLM talks about sports. I used the Philadelphia Eagles as my subject.

Prompt A: “Summarize the Eagles’ 2023 season in one sentence.”

The one-sentence answer gave a broad evaluation: “The Eagles had a strong season but fell short in the playoffs.”

Prompt B: “Summarize the Eagles’ 2023 season in five bullet points.”

The five-bullet version highlighted key details:

regular season record
standout players
offensive strengths
defensive weaknesses
playoff loss



Observations
What stood out is that the structure of the output wasn’t just shorter or longer, the bullet-point response reorganized the story. This shows that prompt phrasing shapes how an LLM frames sports narratives, which is important if you’re using these models for sports journalism or fan engagement.



Philadelphia Eagles

title: Testing AI for Business Brainstorms
text:
AI as a Business Partner


The Image




Testing AI for Business Brainstorms



The Copy Paste

Here’s an example of GPT-5 helping me generate and refine startup ideas during a study session.


The Experiment
In a group project for my business class, we had to come up with a new product idea and outline a marketing plan.
I wondered: could GPT help us think like entrepreneurs, not just write like one?
So I asked:
“Generate 5 startup ideas for college students that solve everyday problems, then outline target customers and pricing strategies.”
The result wasn’t perfect — some ideas were unrealistic — but others felt shockingly plausible. It even categorized them by business model and market segment.


The Prompt and Response

Prompt

    Generate 5 startup ideas for college students that solve everyday problems. For each, describe the target customer, value proposition, and basic pricing model.

Response

    1. DormChef – A meal-prep subscription for students with limited kitchen space. <br>
    2. TextSwap – Peer-to-peer textbook rental app. <br>
    3. CampusConnect – Local networking platform for side hustles and projects. <br>
    4. StudyBuddy AI – Personalized study partner using adaptive learning. <br>
    5. GreenMove – Shared transport service for moving between dorms sustainably.



Reflection

This test showed me how AI can support business ideation — not by replacing creativity, but by accelerating it.
GPT acts like a brainstorming partner that throws ideas at the wall fast, letting you decide which ones to keep.
It’s not about trusting the output blindly, it’s about using it to think faster and broader.




Testing AI for Business Brainstorms
